ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I developed my ability to read novels and watch videos in a foreign language
I improved my grammar and used those grammar structures in speech
Increased knowledge of French grammar and vocabulary, plus further practice in my writing and speaking skills.
I strengthened my French language skills a lot. We reviewed important tenses, like conditional and subjunctive, and engaged with important cultural works, like L'Etranger and Jules et Jim.
I improved my ability to speak, understand, and write French. I learned new words by reading and watching several simple works in French.

French verb tenses, vocabulary, speaking + oral comprehension practice, reading comprehension -- this was the first semester of French where it really felt like I could understand written and spoken material at a normal speaking pace.

My French improved a lot after taking this class! I learned so many new French words and was able to appreciate all the readings with Madame Vysosias. I thoroughly enjoyed every reading and film. I was also able to learn more grammar. The French language is super cool.
How to use canvas modules as well as LingCo

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: good class discussion on texts (although this was slightly stilted on zoom). very interesting texts to read, with good themes covered.

weaknesses: structure not very clearly set out. audio programmes quite long and with required reading in a foreign language this constituted a very high workload. grammar learning seemed somewhat sporadic and teachers and students were not provided with comprehensive grammar sheets until the very end of the semester.
I think the course is generally good.  I found the self-graded homework to sometimes be a little confusing, but that may have been just me.

Strengths: the structure is clear, and it progresses from lesson to lesson well. We get progressively more advanced and build on the knowledge learned earlier. The additional materials were also very good. 

Weaknesses: Of course, the virtual format was not ideal. The workoad could also be a bit high at times, and it was sometimes hard to keep up.

I enjoyed the fact that class time was used to review terms and learn; although it was difficult to accommodate language classes during the pandemic, I do wish more class time was spent giving students the opportunity to practice speaking French.
In terms of weaknesses, I did not enjoy the audio exercises that were given each day. The recorded exercises were of low audio quality, so it was difficult to hear what was being spoken by the narrators, and even at full volume the recordings were not loud enough for me. Many of the recordings did not even match the provided online worksheet. Additionally, the worksheets were all online, and I do not have a tablet or any way to fill out the worksheets, so I just wrote down my answers on whatever scrap paper I could find. I could have printed each individually, but because the worksheets did not belong to any sort of complete catalogue, I would've had to print out exercises every day (and spend money for it). Many of the recordings were twenty to thirty minutes in excess, which is not a bad thing by itself, but the pacing of the recordings was time-consuming; a grammar rule would be introduced and the recording wouldn't give you enough time to think about it, while for easier exercises an excess of twenty seconds was given in between simple questions, meaning you would sit there and wait for half of the time. Skipping across the recording was practically impossible, as the recordings were not visually divided by the worksheet sections, and the media player for the recordings had a small playback bar and no 10 or 15 second skip buttons. Additionally, I am a more visual person, and it was difficult for me to sit in one place and listen carefully to these recordings of such low quality and amplification levels. None of the daily exercises were checked for completion, so that combined with the prior reasons made feeling motivated to complete the exercises very difficult. 
I think if I was given a physical copy of the exercises in one big bundle, and the recordings were amplified and made available on YouTube (or just any better playback tool), I would've had a much better experience.
Additionally, I wish students were given a better idea of what to prepare for for the biweekly Evaluations. It was difficult and unmotivating to navigate around the Modules in Canvas to find what material to study (because they were all located on separate days, the files section of Canvas was not used), and I think just having a review page or something more tangible for students would have been sooo much more helpful. It was already difficult to manage all of the material online, but if all of the files for a unit were kept in a single folder in the files section of Canvas, so that a student can look over all of the material at once, it would've made everything so much easier and motivating.
With all of that said, I did enjoy reading/watching the class material (Petit Nicholas, L'Etranger, and Jules et Jim).

I learned a lot in this class, and my French improved significantly. I do think it's tough to have a language class over Zoom; it would have been very helpful to have a full course packet to print out instead of receiving worksheets and assignments sporadically. I definitely found it hard to keep track of everything given the organization of files on Canvas.

I love this class! It seems like you can engage with it as much as you'd like, as there are plenty of supplemental practice assignments for you to do. But none of it is overwhelming, you just have to work hard and get good results. Madame Vysosias was definitely the biggest strength. She cares about every single one of the students, and she is so accommodating when it comes to mistakes or extensions. Office hours could have been more regular or there could have been a spreadsheet to set up appointments, because they are so so helpful for a student.

The seminars were sort of hard to engage with fully as they were all online otherwise it was a great time. Some of the problems were really just the translation of zoom over to a language learning class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: virtual engagement was difficult, but I think instructors did the best they could, and were very sympathetic with the students given the learning conditions. improvements dont seem necessary given this class will not be online next semester.
I feel the course generally succeeded in adapting to COVID-19, and I have no specific notes as to things that I would like to see changed.

The online testing was effective. Lingco made sense to use. The online blackboard could be confusing at times or have technical issues. It also meant students could not write on the "blackboard" themselves, we had to give answers orally all the time.

It's very difficult to pull off an online language class if students are expected to be speaking the language and feeling motivated towards learning a language. I enjoyed the use of breakout rooms in Zoom, where students could interact which each other while speaking French. Additionally, I enjoyed working on my last Redaction with my partner outside of class over Zoom, and I definitely would've enjoyed more partner activities throughout the semester, as being alone with my partner and working with them allowed me to both appreciate their strengths of French and learn from them.

I think we still maintained a good level of conversation and interaction; I appreciated that it still felt like a relatively well-balanced conversation. The organization of files on Canvas was a little hard to follow -- pages were often posted multiple times, and to find a worksheet you had to go to the page for the corresponding date, so if you didn't remember the exact day that you did a grammar exercise, you had to scroll through modules until you found the correct one. I would've really appreciated it if the full course packet, with all of the semester's worksheets and exercises, were uploaded at the beginning of the semester so that we could follow along that way; instead, I always felt like I was missing a worksheet or was going to miss something.
The virtual format made it less easy to practice spoken French. Maybe we could work on oral exercises in class.

The virtual sessions were fine but J would definitely make sure to use more up-to-date virtual programs. LingCo was not made to handle more than 10 people at once. And after the courses were graded the assignment disappeared .

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: take it in person - if its online, wait. I think french is a really fantastic course to take at yale and even though it has a reputation for being difficult, you do get a lot out of it and I definitely will continue to take french here. make sure your workload with other courses is not too high. if youre taking >5 credits with this class included, I would not recommend.

Generally speaking, yes.  As a language credit, it serves well.  I wouldn't necessarily recommend it as a course for fun, but that is probably at least in part because I am not most interested in languages.
Yes. My French improved by a lot and I got to experience great literature and art that I would have difficulty navigating on my own.

If a student really motivated towards improving their French, I would say maybe. I can't say I really enjoyed the class; maybe I can say I enjoyed seeing my own improvement in French. Although, I don't know how the class is taught regularly.
Yes, if you're excited about learning French and ready and willing to commit a lot of time to it.
I would absolutely recommend it! Professor Vysosias is an absolute gem and a pleasure to be around.
Yes, because there are a lot of core French skills that are discussed in the class that are important for those who seek to study French in the future.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments:
self-guided learning with audio and sheets
mixed media presentations
movies
None
Audio exercises and worksheets
I think that was it- there were canvas modules that went a long with the course that we could do.
